title: How to Make Marshmallow Slime

steps.headline: Add 6 jumbo marshmallows into a mixing bowl with cooking oil.
steps.description: Start by pouring your 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of cooking oil into a large microwave-safe mixing bowl. Now, place the 6 jumbo marshmallows on top. Cooking oil can be anything you like! Olive oil, palm oil, soybean oil, canola oil (rapeseed oil), corn oil, and peanut oil all work.

steps.headline: Microwave the marshmallows and cooking oil for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Place the mixing bowl into the microwave. Set the temperature to "High" and the cooking time to 30 seconds. After microwaving, the marshmallows should be soft enough to mix easily. Cooking time might vary—this time is for a 1200-watt microwave. If you have something a bit more powerful, try 20 seconds before going longer. For weaker microwaves, try 35 to 40 seconds if 30 doesn't cut it.

steps.headline: Mix 1/2 to 1 tablespoon (4.69 to 9.38 grams) of cornstarch powder into the bowl.
steps.description: Pour 1/2 a tablespoon (4.69 grams) of cornstarch into the bowl and mix it in with a small spoon. Once the mixture is cool enough to touch, start using your hands to knead it. Be careful when you first remove the mixture from the microwave—it will be very hot!

steps.headline: Knead the marshmallow mixture and add cornstarch as needed.
steps.description: The act of squeezing your marshmallow paste into a slime with your hands is called kneading. Massage, roll, pull, and squeeze it together. If you find the marshmallows aren't stiff enough, add another 1/2 tablespoon (4.69 grams) of cornstarch for a total of 1 tablespoon (9.38 grams). The goal is to get the mixture feeling like slime. Don't start using your hands until the marshmallows are cool.

steps.headline: Add ¼ cup (31.25 grams) of powdered sugar to the mixture to thicken the slime.
steps.description: Just like cornstarch, powdered sugar will thicken your mixture. You can use it as an alternative to cornstarch, as an additional thickening agent, or just for some flavor! Keep adding ¼ cup (31.25 grams) at a time until you get the desired consistency. Be sure to knead your marshmallow slime after adding sugar to mix it in! Mix in a few drops of food coloring if you want to color your slime.

steps.headline: Store your slime in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days.
steps.description: Put it somewhere at room temperature with minimal humidity. Avoid putting it in the refrigerator or freezing it. Discard the slime once it hardens.

steps.headline: Heat your marshmallows and coconut oil on medium heat.
steps.description: Regardless of your stovetop, medium heat is either dial 5 or—if you can select exact temperature—anywhere between 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C). Dump your 1 bag of mini marshmallows and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil into a large stovetop pot and mix them thoroughly until they melt. Use a whisk or spoon to mix your ingredients.

steps.headline: Pour the marshmallow mixture into a bowl and add cornstarch and icing sugar.
steps.description: Once it's melted, pour your marshmallow melt into a mixing bowl. Add ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of cornstarch and 1/2 cup (62.5 grams) of icing sugar into the bowl. Use a spoon to mix everything together until it's cool enough to use your hands. Stir in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil to prevent stickiness.

steps.headline: Coat a cutting board with cornstarch.
steps.description: Sprinkle cornstarch across your cutting board or another clean, flat surface. Use the back of your spoon to flatten the cornstarch until there's an even layer across the entire cutting board.

steps.headline: Pour your marshmallow mixture onto the cutting board and knead it.
steps.description: After transferring the marshmallow mixture onto a cornstarch-coated surface, start kneading it. Continue squeezing, stretching, and pulling it until you get a slimy consistency. Try rolling your mixture into a ball and then stretching it out flat.

steps.headline: Continue adding coconut oil, cornstarch, and icing sugar for texture.
steps.description: As you knead the marshmallow slime, keep adding ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of cornstarch and 1/2 cup (62.5 grams) of icing sugar until you get a slimy texture you're happy with. If you find that the slime is still too sticky, add another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of coconut oil. Anytime you make an addition, be sure to mix it in thoroughly with your hands. Don't go overboard on additions—remember that you're going to eat it eventually!

steps.headline: Break your slime into 3 pieces and color them with food coloring if you'd like.
steps.description: Pull apart your slime into 3 pieces roughly the same size. Now, add a drop of food coloring to each and knead the slime again to mix it in. Keep adding more drops until you get a color you're happy with. Mix different drops of food coloring to create unique colors.

steps.headline: Put your slime in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days.
steps.description: Place your container in a room temperature area with as little humidity as possible. Don't it them in the freezer or refrigerator. Throw away the slime when it hardens. Swap the container with saran wrap if you'd like.

steps.headline: Mix your 3 egg whites and 1/2 teaspoon (1.69 grams) of cream of tartar.
steps.description: Pour both into a mixing bowl. The easiest way to mix them is with a standing mixer, starting on low speed and then increasing the speed to medium until you notice the formation of soft peaks. You can also use a whisk to mix manually. To check for soft peaks, turn the whisk or whisk attachment upside down—if you see peaks just starting to hold before melting into themselves after 1 to 2 seconds, the mixture is done. Hold the whisk at a 45-degree angle and hold its handle in a gentle grip with your thumb and fingers.

steps.headline: Heat water, sugar, salt, and vanilla to 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C).
steps.description: Pour ⁄3 cup (160 mL) of water, 3/4 cups (150 grams) of sugar, 1/4 teaspoon (1.42 grams) of salt, and 2 to 3 drops of vanilla extract into a medium saucepan. Now, place it on medium heat and wait. Check its temperature with a candy thermometer and take it off the stove once it hits 230 °F (110 °C). Medium heat is 5 on the dial or anywhere between 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C).

steps.headline: Remove the sugar mixture from the heat and mix with your eggs.
steps.description: Once the egg mixture reaches 230 °F (110 °C), remove it from the element. Now, add it to your egg whites and cream of tartar and continue mixing. If you're using a stand mixer, keep it on medium speed.

steps.headline: Add ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) of cotton candy extract into your mixture.
steps.description: If you're using a stand mixer, add the cotton candy extract slowly on medium. If you're using a whisk, add a little bit at a time and whisk it into the mixture immediately after. Continue this process until all of the extract is mixed in evenly. Don't add the extract too quickly or you might make your egg whites chunky.

steps.headline: Increase your mixing speed until the slime doubles in volume.
steps.description: With a stand mixer, set the mixing speed to high and wait. If you're using a whisk, increase your speed as much as possible. Regardless of your mixing method, stop once the mixture has doubled in volume. If you're mixing with a whisk, hold the mixing bowl with your non-dominant hand as you increase your mixing speed. Add green food coloring during this step to give your slime color.

steps.headline: Apply your slime to cakes and pastries.
steps.description: You can use your marshmallow slime in any way you want, but it tastes best with cakes and pastries. For example, top off a cake with your slime or poke a hole into a cupcake and fill it up. Don't be afraid to get messy and give your desserts a slimy, messy look!

steps.headline: Store your slime in an airtight container for 1 to 2 days.
steps.description: Make sure it sits at room temperature with minimal humidity. If you want to use it on a dessert again, put it on the stovetop on medium heat until it reaches 230 °F (110 °C). Just don't expect to get the same slimy texture when reheating! Discard the slime once it hardens. Don’t reheat the slime more than once.

text: Microwave Marshmallow Slime Add 6 jumbo marshmallows into a mixing bowl with cooking oil. Start by pouring your 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of cooking oil into a large microwave-safe mixing bowl. Now, place the 6 jumbo marshmallows on top. Cooking oil can be anything you like! Olive oil, palm oil, soybean oil, canola oil (rapeseed oil), corn oil, and peanut oil all work. Microwave the marshmallows and cooking oil for 30 seconds. Place the mixing bowl into the microwave. Set the temperature to "High" and the cooking time to 30 seconds. After microwaving, the marshmallows should be soft enough to mix easily. Cooking time might vary—this time is for a 1200-watt microwave. If you have something a bit more powerful, try 20 seconds before going longer. For weaker microwaves, try 35 to 40 seconds if 30 doesn't cut it. Mix 1/2 to 1 tablespoon (4.69 to 9.38 grams) of cornstarch powder into the bowl. Pour 1/2 a tablespoon (4.69 grams) of cornstarch into the bowl and mix it in with a small spoon. Once the mixture is cool enough to touch, start using your hands to knead it. Be careful when you first remove the mixture from the microwave—it will be very hot! Knead the marshmallow mixture and add cornstarch as needed. The act of squeezing your marshmallow paste into a slime with your hands is called kneading. Massage, roll, pull, and squeeze it together. If you find the marshmallows aren't stiff enough, add another 1/2 tablespoon (4.69 grams) of cornstarch for a total of 1 tablespoon (9.38 grams). The goal is to get the mixture feeling like slime. Don't start using your hands until the marshmallows are cool. Add ¼ cup (31.25 grams) of powdered sugar to the mixture to thicken the slime. Just like cornstarch, powdered sugar will thicken your mixture. You can use it as an alternative to cornstarch, as an additional thickening agent, or just for some flavor! Keep adding ¼ cup (31.25 grams) at a time until you get the desired consistency. Be sure to knead your marshmallow slime after adding sugar to mix it in! Mix in a few drops of food coloring if you want to color your slime. Store your slime in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days. Put it somewhere at room temperature with minimal humidity. Avoid putting it in the refrigerator or freezing it. Discard the slime once it hardens. Stovetop Marshmallow Slime Heat your marshmallows and coconut oil on medium heat. Regardless of your stovetop, medium heat is either dial 5 or—if you can select exact temperature—anywhere between 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C). Dump your 1 bag of mini marshmallows and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil into a large stovetop pot and mix them thoroughly until they melt. Use a whisk or spoon to mix your ingredients. Pour the marshmallow mixture into a bowl and add cornstarch and icing sugar. Once it's melted, pour your marshmallow melt into a mixing bowl. Add ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of cornstarch and 1/2 cup (62.5 grams) of icing sugar into the bowl. Use a spoon to mix everything together until it's cool enough to use your hands. Stir in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil to prevent stickiness. Coat a cutting board with cornstarch. Sprinkle cornstarch across your cutting board or another clean, flat surface. Use the back of your spoon to flatten the cornstarch until there's an even layer across the entire cutting board. Pour your marshmallow mixture onto the cutting board and knead it. After transferring the marshmallow mixture onto a cornstarch-coated surface, start kneading it. Continue squeezing, stretching, and pulling it until you get a slimy consistency. Try rolling your mixture into a ball and then stretching it out flat. Continue adding coconut oil, cornstarch, and icing sugar for texture. As you knead the marshmallow slime, keep adding ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of cornstarch and 1/2 cup (62.5 grams) of icing sugar until you get a slimy texture you're happy with. If you find that the slime is still too sticky, add another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of coconut oil. Anytime you make an addition, be sure to mix it in thoroughly with your hands. Don't go overboard on additions—remember that you're going to eat it eventually! Break your slime into 3 pieces and color them with food coloring if you'd like. Pull apart your slime into 3 pieces roughly the same size. Now, add a drop of food coloring to each and knead the slime again to mix it in. Keep adding more drops until you get a color you're happy with. Mix different drops of food coloring to create unique colors. Put your slime in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days. Place your container in a room temperature area with as little humidity as possible. Don't it them in the freezer or refrigerator. Throw away the slime when it hardens. Swap the container with saran wrap if you'd like. Marshmallow Slime Cake Mix your 3 egg whites and 1/2 teaspoon (1.69 grams) of cream of tartar. Pour both into a mixing bowl. The easiest way to mix them is with a standing mixer, starting on low speed and then increasing the speed to medium until you notice the formation of soft peaks. You can also use a whisk to mix manually. To check for soft peaks, turn the whisk or whisk attachment upside down—if you see peaks just starting to hold before melting into themselves after 1 to 2 seconds, the mixture is done. Hold the whisk at a 45-degree angle and hold its handle in a gentle grip with your thumb and fingers. Heat water, sugar, salt, and vanilla to 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C). Pour ⁄3 cup (160 mL) of water, 3/4 cups (150 grams) of sugar, 1/4 teaspoon (1.42 grams) of salt, and 2 to 3 drops of vanilla extract into a medium saucepan. Now, place it on medium heat and wait. Check its temperature with a candy thermometer and take it off the stove once it hits 230 °F (110 °C). Medium heat is 5 on the dial or anywhere between 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C). Remove the sugar mixture from the heat and mix with your eggs. Once the egg mixture reaches 230 °F (110 °C), remove it from the element. Now, add it to your egg whites and cream of tartar and continue mixing. If you're using a stand mixer, keep it on medium speed. Add ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) of cotton candy extract into your mixture. If you're using a stand mixer, add the cotton candy extract slowly on medium. If you're using a whisk, add a little bit at a time and whisk it into the mixture immediately after. Continue this process until all of the extract is mixed in evenly. Don't add the extract too quickly or you might make your egg whites chunky. Increase your mixing speed until the slime doubles in volume. With a stand mixer, set the mixing speed to high and wait. If you're using a whisk, increase your speed as much as possible. Regardless of your mixing method, stop once the mixture has doubled in volume. If you're mixing with a whisk, hold the mixing bowl with your non-dominant hand as you increase your mixing speed. Add green food coloring during this step to give your slime color. Apply your slime to cakes and pastries. You can use your marshmallow slime in any way you want, but it tastes best with cakes and pastries. For example, top off a cake with your slime or poke a hole into a cupcake and fill it up. Don't be afraid to get messy and give your desserts a slimy, messy look! Store your slime in an airtight container for 1 to 2 days. Make sure it sits at room temperature with minimal humidity. If you want to use it on a dessert again, put it on the stovetop on medium heat until it reaches 230 °F (110 °C). Just don't expect to get the same slimy texture when reheating! Discard the slime once it hardens. Don’t reheat the slime more than once.
sentences: Microwave Marshmallow Slime Add 6 jumbo marshmallows into a mixing bowl with cooking oil.
Start by pouring your 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of cooking oil into a large microwave-safe mixing bowl.
Now, place the 6 jumbo marshmallows on top.
Cooking oil can be anything you like!
Olive oil, palm oil, soybean oil, canola oil (rapeseed oil), corn oil, and peanut oil all work.
Microwave the marshmallows and cooking oil for 30 seconds.
Place the mixing bowl into the microwave.
Set the temperature to "High" and the cooking time to 30 seconds.
After microwaving, the marshmallows should be soft enough to mix easily.
Cooking time might vary—this time is for a 1200-watt microwave.
If you have something a bit more powerful, try 20 seconds before going longer.
For weaker microwaves, try 35 to 40 seconds if 30 doesn't cut it.
Mix 1/2 to 1 tablespoon (4.69 to 9.38 grams) of cornstarch powder into the bowl.
Pour 1/2 a tablespoon (4.69 grams) of cornstarch into the bowl and mix it in with a small spoon.
Once the mixture is cool enough to touch, start using your hands to knead it.
Be careful when you first remove the mixture from the microwave—it will be very hot!
Knead the marshmallow mixture and add cornstarch as needed.
The act of squeezing your marshmallow paste into a slime with your hands is called kneading.
Massage, roll, pull, and squeeze it together.
If you find the marshmallows aren't stiff enough, add another 1/2 tablespoon (4.69 grams) of cornstarch for a total of 1 tablespoon (9.38 grams).
The goal is to get the mixture feeling like slime.
Don't start using your hands until the marshmallows are cool.
Add ¼ cup (31.25 grams) of powdered sugar to the mixture to thicken the slime.
Just like cornstarch, powdered sugar will thicken your mixture.
You can use it as an alternative to cornstarch, as an additional thickening agent, or just for some flavor!
Keep adding ¼ cup (31.25 grams) at a time until you get the desired consistency.
Be sure to knead your marshmallow slime after adding sugar to mix it in!
Mix in a few drops of food coloring if you want to color your slime.
Store your slime in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days.
Put it somewhere at room temperature with minimal humidity.
Avoid putting it in the refrigerator or freezing it.
Discard the slime once it hardens.
Stovetop Marshmallow Slime Heat your marshmallows and coconut oil on medium heat.
Regardless of your stovetop, medium heat is either dial 5 or—if you can select exact temperature—anywhere between 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C).
Dump your 1 bag of mini marshmallows and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil into a large stovetop pot and mix them thoroughly until they melt.
Use a whisk or spoon to mix your ingredients.
Pour the marshmallow mixture into a bowl and add cornstarch and icing sugar.
Once it's melted, pour your marshmallow melt into a mixing bowl.
Add ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of cornstarch and 1/2 cup (62.5 grams) of icing sugar into the bowl.
Use a spoon to mix everything together until it's cool enough to use your hands.
Stir in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of coconut oil to prevent stickiness.
Coat a cutting board with cornstarch.
Sprinkle cornstarch across your cutting board or another clean, flat surface.
Use the back of your spoon to flatten the cornstarch until there's an even layer across the entire cutting board.
Pour your marshmallow mixture onto the cutting board and knead it.
After transferring the marshmallow mixture onto a cornstarch-coated surface, start kneading it.
Continue squeezing, stretching, and pulling it until you get a slimy consistency.
Try rolling your mixture into a ball and then stretching it out flat.
Continue adding coconut oil, cornstarch, and icing sugar for texture.
As you knead the marshmallow slime, keep adding ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of cornstarch and 1/2 cup (62.5 grams) of icing sugar until you get a slimy texture you're happy with.
If you find that the slime is still too sticky, add another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of coconut oil.
Anytime you make an addition, be sure to mix it in thoroughly with your hands.
Don't go overboard on additions—remember that you're going to eat it eventually!
Break your slime into 3 pieces and color them with food coloring if you'd like.
Pull apart your slime into 3 pieces roughly the same size.
Now, add a drop of food coloring to each and knead the slime again to mix it in.
Keep adding more drops until you get a color you're happy with.
Mix different drops of food coloring to create unique colors.
Put your slime in an airtight container for 2 to 3 days.
Place your container in a room temperature area with as little humidity as possible.
Don't it them in the freezer or refrigerator.
Throw away the slime when it hardens.
Swap the container with saran wrap if you'd like.
Marshmallow Slime Cake Mix your 3 egg whites and 1/2 teaspoon (1.69 grams) of cream of tartar.
Pour both into a mixing bowl.
The easiest way to mix them is with a standing mixer, starting on low speed and then increasing the speed to medium until you notice the formation of soft peaks.
You can also use a whisk to mix manually.
To check for soft peaks, turn the whisk or whisk attachment upside down—if you see peaks just starting to hold before melting into themselves after 1 to 2 seconds, the mixture is done.
Hold the whisk at a 45-degree angle and hold its handle in a gentle grip with your thumb and fingers.
Heat water, sugar, salt, and vanilla to 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C).
Pour ⁄3 cup (160 mL) of water, 3/4 cups (150 grams) of sugar, 1/4 teaspoon (1.42 grams) of salt, and 2 to 3 drops of vanilla extract into a medium saucepan.
Now, place it on medium heat and wait.
Check its temperature with a candy thermometer and take it off the stove once it hits 230 °F (110 °C).
Medium heat is 5 on the dial or anywhere between 300 to 400 °F (149 to 204 °C).
Remove the sugar mixture from the heat and mix with your eggs.
Once the egg mixture reaches 230 °F (110 °C), remove it from the element.
Now, add it to your egg whites and cream of tartar and continue mixing.
If you're using a stand mixer, keep it on medium speed.
Add ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) of cotton candy extract into your mixture.
If you're using a stand mixer, add the cotton candy extract slowly on medium.
If you're using a whisk, add a little bit at a time and whisk it into the mixture immediately after.
Continue this process until all of the extract is mixed in evenly.
Don't add the extract too quickly or you might make your egg whites chunky.
Increase your mixing speed until the slime doubles in volume.
With a stand mixer, set the mixing speed to high and wait.
If you're using a whisk, increase your speed as much as possible.
Regardless of your mixing method, stop once the mixture has doubled in volume.
If you're mixing with a whisk, hold the mixing bowl with your non-dominant hand as you increase your mixing speed.
Add green food coloring during this step to give your slime color.
Apply your slime to cakes and pastries.
You can use your marshmallow slime in any way you want, but it tastes best with cakes and pastries.
For example, top off a cake with your slime or poke a hole into a cupcake and fill it up.
Don't be afraid to get messy and give your desserts a slimy, messy look!
Store your slime in an airtight container for 1 to 2 days.
Make sure it sits at room temperature with minimal humidity.
If you want to use it on a dessert again, put it on the stovetop on medium heat until it reaches 230 °F (110 °C).
Just don't expect to get the same slimy texture when reheating!
Discard the slime once it hardens.
Don’t reheat the slime more than once.
